Open Water (Fresh)
bCOMEx-w6.memHandModelNotes:
Prefers to feed in deep waters, <4m (Mallory and Metz 1999). ***Modeling restrict open water to larger lake bodies. Amy Silvano 08sept05

Changed this to include only portions of water bodies 500m from shore. MJR 20aug07.

Amy misinterpreted the deep water comment of Mallory and Mertz (1999). Actually prefers to feed in waters LESS THAN 4m, i.e. shallower waters, but will feed in deeper water during winter months. My previous model limited the distribution only to waters at least 500m from shore. I removed hand modeling to include all waters as per the unlimited buffer INTO (9999). MJR 11 February 2008.

references: Mcnicol, D. K., R. K. Ross, M. L. Mallory, and L. A. Brisebois. 1995. Trends in waterfowl populations: evidence of recovery from acidification. Chapter 16, Pp. 203-217 in Environmental restoration and recovery of an industrial region. (Gunn, J. M., Ed.) Springer-Verlag, New York.

Desgranges, J. L., and B. Houde. 1989. Effects of acidity and other environmental parameters on the distribution of lacustrine birds in Quebec. In J. L. DesGranges (editor) Studies of the Effects of Acidification on Aquatic Wildlife in Canada:Lacustrine B
American Ornithologists' Union (AOU). 1983. Check-list of North American Birds, 6th edition. Allen Press, Inc., Lawrence, Kansas. 877 pp.
Haapanen, A. and L. Nilsson. 1979. Breeding waterfowl populations in northern Fennoscandia. Ornis. Scand. 10:145-219.
Erskine, A. J. 1972. Populations, movements and seasonal distribution of mergansers. Can. Wildl. Serv. Rep. Ser. no. 17.
White, H. C. 1957. Food and natural history of mergansers on salmon waters in the maritime provinces of Canada. Fish Res. Board Canada Bull. no. 116.
Blancher, P. J., D. K. McNicol, R. K. Ross, C. H. R. Wedeles, and P. Morrison. 1992. Towards a model of acidification effects on waterfowl in eastern Canada. Environ. Pollut. 78:57-63.
Brown, B. T. 1990. Nesting common mergansers in Chihuahua, Mexico. Southwest Nat. 35:88-89.
Terres, J.K. 1980. The Audubon Society encyclopedia of North American birds. Alfred A. Knopf, New York.
Zicus, M. C. and S. K. Hennes. 1988. Cavity nesting waterfowl in Minnesota. Wildfowl 39:115-123.
Mallory, M., and K. Metz. 1999. Common Merganser (Mergus merganser).  In The Birds of North America, No. 442 (A. Poole and F. Gill, eds.). The Birds of North America, Inc., Philadelphia, PA.

NatureServe. 2009. NatureServe Explorer: An online encyclopedia of life [web application]. Version 7.1. NatureServe, Arlington, Virginia. Available http://www.natureserve.org/explorer. (Accessed: March, 2010 ).
Wood, C. C. 1985. Aggregative response of Common Mergansers (Mergus merganser): predicting flock size and abundance on Vancouver Island salmon streams. Can. J. Fish. Aquat. Sci. 42:1259-1271.
Bellrose, F. C. 1980. Ducks, geese and swans of North America. Stackpole Books, Harrisburg, Pennsylvania. 540 pp.
Palmer, R. S., editor. 1976. Handbook of North American birds. Vol. 3. Waterfowl (concluded). Eiders, wood ducks, diving ducks, mergansers, stifftails. Yale Univ. Press, New Haven. 560 pp.
Robb, J. R. 1986. The importance of nesting cavities and brood habitat to Wood Duck production. Master’s thesis, Ohio State Univ., Columbus.
habitat_description:
In General:
Breeding habitat for Common Mergansers includes lakes and rivers bordered by forests mature enough to provide suitable tree cavities, although rock cavities, spaces among tree roots, and holes in banks may be used in some areas; northern limit of breeding range follows limit of open boreal forest (Palmer 1976, Haapanen and Nilsson 1979, Bellrose 1980). Prefers nesting near large water bodies surrounded by conifers or mixed forests, oligotrophic, moderate to high pH with inorganic sediments and plentiful fish (Zicus and Hennes 1988, DesGranges 1989, Blancher et al. 1992, McNicol et al. 1995). During brood-rearing, drainage systems are important because females move broods downstream along these to larger rivers, lakes, or bays (White 1957, Erskine 1972, Wood 1985, McNicol et al. 1995)(quoted directly from Mallory and Metz 1999).

Southwest:
Nevada: resident in selected areas & transient statewide. Colorado: breeds, primarily in western mountains; common-abundant winter resident in western valleys, mountain parks and on eastern plains. In mountain parks, it may occur as spring/fall migrant. Rare-uncommon summer resident in central and west Colorado. It occurs in mountains west of Continental Divide. Also breeds on northeastern plains. Habitat: reservoirs and rivers. Uncommon transient and winter resident on larger lakes and rivers in the Southwestern lowlands, preferring freshwater with ample fish supply. Common resident in most montane rivers during breeding season and extending out into nonforested rivers, lakes, and reservoirs at othe times. Ocurs in areas of clear water supporting large fish populations. Nesting adults, occur in tree cavities, rock crevices, sometimes under boulders and dense shrubbery. Wintering in most of the area but also breeding in parts of 5 states. Sierra Nevadas, northwest Nevada, central & west Colorado, north-central New Mexico. Breeds locally in west Utah, below Mogollon Rim in Arizona, Mogollon Highlands of southwest New Mexico. Winters both on fresh and salt water but most frequently on freshwater. Breeding habitat: lakes & rivers bordered by forests mature enough to provide suitable tree cavities. Prefers nesting near large water bodies surrounded by conifers or mixed forests, oligotrophic, moderate-high pH with inorganic sediments and plentiful fish.  Migratory habitat: primarily shallow water feeding areas on rivers, large reservoirs. Winter habitat: large lakes, reservoirs, rivers. Tends to winter on freshwater. In Utah, the species is common during migration, uncommon during winter, rare during summer. Is known to have nested at a few scattered locations in state. Breeding habitat is lakes and rivers often in mountainous areas. During migration and winter, it uses large lakes and rivers and occasionally coastal bays.

Southeast:
Mallory and Metz (1999) describe the primary winter habitat of common mergansers as large lakes, reserviors, rivers, coastal bays, and estuaries and harbors.
